job_title: Mental Health Support Worker in London, England
pros: Lovely people in the team the most down to earth people and my manager supported and guided me and cared for my opinion. You are doing a very touching job changing people's lives and helping them more than their social workers or GPs help and they really appreciate it. You are not sat at a desk all day, people's person kind of job to make you more social and friendly. The job is so exhausting that if you move to another job after this one you can do anything with the strength you've built. Understanding to culture and inclusion.
cons: The body of the organisation is so self centred about everything being 100% but don't realise that is at the cost of their employees health. They want everything to be perfect and criticise you if it's not and when you explain their expectations are beyond the hours you do they put them blame on other things. Job requires outreach travel and they refuse to help with transport. You are working within the mental health sector with Hestia and with vulnerable people but your own mental health becomes on the line. There is sadly no progression in this organisation. Upper management have no knowledge of what is going with their employees and are bitter when you try to make them understand. Job requires a lot of admin even though it's an outreach role. You're doing way more than what you get paid, was doing more work for clients than the health care professionals seeing them.

pros:
Great local team

Invaluable experience in the field

Meaningful direct work with service users
cons:
Low salary for unsociable hours 

Training not specialised enough to address needs of specific services. Some trainings are run by more senior HQ staff who have no business running them - they have neither the relevant experience in the topic nor adequate qualifications for it. 

Career progression very difficult as they don't actively mentor staff 

Services rely on individual workers' abilities to manage risk etc . instead of HQ making sure workers have in-depth continuous upskilling and support to do their jobs safely 

The work load is completely unrealistic, so managers regularly (often daily) work over time yet their supervisors don't address it - so they silently condone practices that lead to burnout and horrible work-life balance. 

Staff are an afterthought, always. Not sure what's going on in HQ, but this culture is a sure way to torpedo an organisation's long-term reputation.

Constant expansion and new contracts at the expense of quality. This leads to services being opened in a haphazard way without enough thought about what is actually needed and helpful, both for service users and staff. 

A lot of talk about values that mostly feels empty due to how things are run (or rather, not run) by HQ.

Very quick turnover of staff due to all the above so it's hard to build resilient teams. 

Revolving door of agency staff and pool workers - not great for service users!

It's a shame and pity as the work is much needed and valuable.

pros:
One gets to see the system of mental health care in the UK.
Some good people there with sincere intentions.
Some decent services provided to the community.
cons:
Frontline staff are not given autonomy or empowered to use their skills, especially since the pandemic. Micromanaging is commonplace and targets and stats seem to be the be all and end all for upper management, this has caused needless stress to frontline workers, and team leaders, during one of the most stressful times to be a frontline worker. 
Grievances are gatekeeped by HR, who are not impartial.
The CEO guilt tripped staff during pandemic when they had legitimate health and safety concerns about Hestia policy. In all staff emails he would use manipulative wording, for instance ' I'm sure staff would not like anything to happen to our service users' so as to make staff feel guilty about questioning health and safety policy. This was very disappointing behaviour from the person most responsible for leading by example.
At the service I worked in, 9 people left over a 3 month period due to the direction the organisation was going and due to the behaviour of service and area manager. This has not changed and HR have buried their heads In the sand about this. 
The organisation is very slow in getting staff feedback on major policy changes and implementing changes based on this feedback. In many cases they implement policy changes which effect staff and service users without consultation, this has led to excessive stress on frontline workers and poor service delivery to service users.

review_title: Huddleston Close - amazing place to work
job_title: Support Worker in Bethnal Green, England
pros: Friendly staff, supportive manager, range of experience
cons: Low pay, lack of career progression opportunities

pros:
Hestia is a truly brilliant place to work. As a charity working with a large number of vulnerable people, it has a responsibility towards the sector to ensure that it is not shying away from the tough work that is so vital in improving people's lives. 

Due to this need, it is a fast paced and demanding organisation with many of us working above and beyond expectations to ensure that we are playing our role in the sector.

Hestia embraces change very well and listens to the concerns of those of us who may voice ideas on how to change ways of working. It advocates a bottom up way of management which has resulted in many positive changes.

Because of how demanding this work can be, many people may can feel overwhelmed but there are some truly great managers in the organisation and I feel that the strategic leadership is moving in a positive direction. 

Overall, Hestia listens to its employees, changes ways of working for the benefit of its service users, and looks after those of us who work hard to ensure we are doing our part.
cons: At one point, there had been a lot of paperwork involved in the role. But for the last few months this has decreased and the organisation has cut unnecessary paperwork for staff and service users.

review_title: Hestia is best support agency I have worked for - let me tell you why
pros:
I have worked with Hestia since May 2016.   I started as a support worker and have been encouraged to progress and am now a team leader of a busy floating support service.

I have found the managers around me and my area manager incredibly supportive.  They have always treated me as an equal at all times and they listen.   HR team has also been supportive as I have had to learn recruitment and again even those in higher management are always willing to listen and guide and additionally are open to suggestions too.

I have a great team around me and we achieve some amazing results for our service users - which is why I do what I do and why joining Hestia is the best thing I have done.
cons:
To be honest the cons are more about the funding restrictions placed on local authorities which means reduced budgets for services - yet more paperwork.   It has to be said that wages are not great - but if recruited you can learn a lot and there is always the possibility of climbing the ladder.
Hestia are looking to bring in a new database that will reduce the paperwork some - but to be honest - it is part of the job and needful to evidence what we do.

review_title: Words are cheap...and thats all you're offering!
pros:
The staff I managed put up with the problems they and I experienced every single day without letting them affect the work we delivered to the service users we helped - The staff work hard regardless of the lack of support from the organisation.
Complaints are made, and over the years I worked here I brought them up time after time but things didnt change or improve.
Ive read the responses from HR to these reviews and reading them I know exactly who is responding to these reviews and unfortunately this person is missing what each reviewer is writing. She is not acknowledging the issues raised, but is saying what she has been programmed to say in the organisations defence. 
Unfortunately the problem with this organisation starts at the top with the CEO. He instills FEAR right across head office and then right across the organisation. He is a dinosaur who has been at the organisation over 15 years and during this time he has instilled his dictatorship right across every senior manager and director. This further instills a culture in them to simply ignore what the staff are crying out for and poor practices where if he doesn't like you, you are out!
I have seen enough staff pushed out of the organisation over my time, and others suffer every single day with stress issues that then lead them to go on long term sick leave - He doesn't care!
The only positive is that the staff in our services work to the best of their ability for the service users despite the horrible culture of this organisation!
cons:
The organisation talks about The Hestia Approach as if its some kind of unique and earth shattering way of working! The basis of it being to work together, help each other, and collaborate on a common goal. Ummmmmm, why is the organisation so proud of this approach? Surely this is the BASIC way that EVERY NORMAL ORGANISATION works on a daily basis! The fact that they think its revolutionary and new tells us that this organisation has been working under a negative model for the 47 years the organisation has been running!  I think its sad and disappointing that good staff have to put up with such a poor example of a CEO and that he drives his negative cultural values across the organisation, facing good staff out and keeping and promoting those who are his little militant robots! 
The organisation is working in the dark ages and without a change at the top, nothing good will come out of Hestia!
The Trustees are oblivious to the poor practices of the organisation and I don't understand how they get away with ruining staff lives?
The organisations moto is 'Empowering people, changing lives' and this may be true when they talk about service users but what about staff? More like 'Enslaving staff, destroying lives!' 
After years of putting up with it myself, and seeing my staff leave and suffer because head office wouldnt implement positive change, I had enough and am happier for not being there!
